item.title: What Matters
item.description: Everyday Treasures by Law Aritao I would like to create something new every day. I would like to take a picture, tell a story, share an idea, or illustrate something. I would like to say a kind word, hold my wife’s hand, hug my children, tell them I love them. I would like eat something tasty, walk a few miles, listen to music. I would like to make a wish, say a prayer, think kind thoughts for others.

item.title: Reflecting on the Why (of this Site)
item.description: by Law Aritao Reflections on Why I want to explore why I am doing this blog and why I consider Hugo and Github pages a great choice. Why Hugo and Github Pages? In the past twelve months, I explored Wordpress, Ghost, Wix, Wordpress/Ghost on various platforms: Google Cloud, Amazon Web Services, Azure, Linode, Digital Ocean, and Vultr. I also tried creating a static site and hosting it on Amazon Amplify.

item.title: Beautiful Markdown
item.description: by Law Aritao Beautiful Markdown Hugo, my preferred site generator, supports Markdown, a beautiful markup language that’s been around since 2004. I love Markdown. It is simple. It is beautiful. It is intuitive (once you get the hang of some fundamentals). It’s gotten so bad that I now have several Markdown editors on my devices, and I wouldn’t mind more. I use Caret, Inkdrop, Nota, and SimpleNote. Caret is nice because it is available on both Windows and MacOs, and it is gorgeous.

item.title: A Learning Adventure - Part Two
item.description: by Law Aritao I walk farther down the path of Hugo and Github Pages. So much fun. Photo credit: Thomas Willmott on unsplash. Deeper Down the Rabbit Hole As I worked on site content and structure, I switched to this theme for its design and overall quality. Reading the theme’s documentation gave me some additional lessons in the way Hugo creates the static output (Hugo’s lookup order). The relatively painless switch in themes gave me a greater appreciation for Hugo’s design.

item.title: A Learning Adventure via Github + Hugo
item.description: by Law Aritao Wonderful Github Somtimes I wish I could just learn by osmosis. With Github, I found the next best thing. Photo credit: Dmitry Ratushny on unsplash Down the Rabbit Hole I recently figured out how to use Github pages to host a Hugo-created blog site (got interested because of this. As I was learning the method, I got hooked on the beauty of Github. After tinkering and understanding Github a little bit more, I have fallen in love with it.
